title: Incarcerated Inguinal Hernia
diagnosis_topic: Irreducible inguinal hernia with risk of strangulation
setup_script: A 60-year-old man with a long-standing right inguinal hernia presents with acute groin pain and a bulge that cannot be reduced. He also reports nausea and vomiting.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 135/85 mmHg, HR 98 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 37.6 C.
Tender, non-reducible mass in right inguinal canal; overlying skin erythematous but no skin necrosis; no peritonitis.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident attempts gentle manual reduction (taxis) after analgesia and Trendelenburg positioning

dynamic_flow.reply: Herniated small bowel loop with compromised venous flow; no perfusion defect yet.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident keeps patient NPO, starts IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics
If resident proceeds to emergent surgical repair
dynamic_flow.reply: Inguinal exploration reveals strangulated segment of small bowel requiring resection and hernia repair with mesh avoided in contaminated field.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses elective vs. emergent repair
dynamic_flow.reply: Elective repair recommended for symptomatic hernias to prevent incarceration.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident explains types of repair
dynamic_flow.reply: Open Lichtenstein vs. laparoscopic (TAPP/TEP); choose based on patient factors and surgeon expertise.
Pain control, early ambulation and restrictions on heavy lifting for 4-6 weeks.
Importance of recognizing signs of recurrence or contralateral hernia and weight control.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of incarcerated hernia and risk of strangulation
Appropriate attempts at reduction and indications for emergent surgery
Preoperative preparation including antibiotics and fluid resuscitation
Surgical decision-making regarding bowel resection and mesh use
Postoperative care and prevention of future hernias
